title: RAF Wildenrath
text:
Royal Air Force Wildenrath, commonly known as RAF Wildenrath, was a <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> (RAF) <a href="military%20airbase">military airbase</a> near <a href="Wildenrath">Wildenrath</a> in <a href="North%20Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a>, Germany, that operated from 1952 to 1992. Wildenrath was the first of four 'clutch' stations built for the RAF in <a href="Germany">Germany</a> during the early 1950s. It opened on 15 January , and was followed by <a href="RAF%20Geilenkirchen">RAF Geilenkirchen</a> on 24 May , <a href="RAF%20Br%C3%BCggen">RAF Brüggen</a> in July 1953, and <a href="RAF%20Laarbruch">RAF Laarbruch</a> that opened on 15 October . RAF Wildenrath, RAF Brüggen, and RAF Laarbruch were physically close to each other, and came under the auspices of <a href="NATO">NATO</a>'s <a href="Second%20Allied%20Tactical%20Air%20Force">Second Allied Tactical Air Force</a> (2ATAF).
RAF service.
In 1953, the Station Commander was <a href="Group%20Captain">Group Captain</a> <a href="Johnnie%20Johnson%20%28RAF%20officer%29">JE 'Johnnie' Johnson</a>, a top-scoring British '<a href="flying%20ace">ace</a>' <a href="fighter%20pilot">fighter pilot</a> of the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a>. There were two <a href="Canadair%20Sabre">Canadair Sabre F.4</a> squadrons (Nos <a href="No.%2067%20Squadron%20RAF">67</a> and <a href="No.%2071%20Squadron%20RAF">71</a> Squadrons RAF), and a Sabre <a href="Operational%20conversion%20unit">conversion</a> <a href="Flight%20%28military%20unit%29">flight</a>. Also on site were 724 Signals Unit (Fighter control radar), 402 Air Stores Park, a unit of the <a href="RAF%20Regiment">RAF Regiment</a>, and a <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> detachment that maintained landlines (AFS).
On 15 January 1956, <a href="No.%2088%20Squadron%20RAF">88 Sqn</a> reformed with <a href="English%20Electric%20Canberra">B(I).8 Canberras</a> at Wildenrath, and was renumbered <a href="No.%2014%20Squadron%20RAF">14 Sqn</a> on 17 December 1962. (Reference 88 Sqn history)
From the late 1950s to 1970, Wildenrath was home to <a href="No.%2014%20Squadron%20RAF">14 Squadron</a> and <a href="No.%2017%20Squadron%20RAF">17 Squadron</a>; the former flew <a href="English%20Electric%20Canberra">B(I).8 Canberras</a>, and was part of the 2nd ATAF <a href="Tactical%20nuclear%20weapon">tactical nuclear</a> <a href="Quick%20reaction%20force">strike force</a>. The locations of their quick-readiness dispersals can still be seen to the south of the former main gate. No. 17 Squadron flew the PR.7 Canberra, and the two squadrons' 'in house' T.4 training aircraft were combined into the so-called 'T4 Flight' as a separate sub-unit, forming a useful additional resource for 2ATAF senior officers to use to maintain their flying hours. In the early 1960s, 88 Squadron Canberras were also based at Wildenrath. The base was also used for '<a href="Casualty%20evacuation">CasEvac</a>' (emergency casualty evacuations) usually to the United Kingdom. In November 1956, the RAF operated a three-day airlift to fly over of humanitarian relief supplies from Wildenrath to <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, for the Red Cross to distribute in Hungary during the <a href="Hungarian%20Revolution%20of%201956">Hungarian uprising</a>, before the revolt was ended with Soviet military intervention.
In 1960, the Station Commander was Group Captain 'Bats' Barthold, and 17 Squadron was commanded by Wing Commander Dugald 'Buster' Lumsden, who accepted the squadron's <a href="Military%20colours">colours</a> presented by <a href="Marshal%20of%20the%20Royal%20Air%20Force">Marshal of the Royal Air Force</a> <a href="Sir%20Dermot%20Boyle">Sir Dermot Boyle</a>. At this time, the <a href="commanding%20officer">commanding officer</a> of 2ATAF (former <a href="Battle%20of%20Britain">Battle of Britain</a> fighter pilot, Sir <a href="Christopher%20Foxley-Norris">Christopher Foxley-Norris</a>) had a <a href="Vickers%20Valetta">Vickers Valetta</a> aircraft as his personal transport, its lower fuselage and wings kept highly polished by the ground-crew of the <a href="RAF%20Germany">RAF Germany</a> (RAFG) Communication Flight. The aircraft was eventually declared un-airworthy due to many of its rivet-heads having been polished off. It can be seen today in the <a href="RAF%20Museum">RAF Museum</a> at <a href="Hendon">Hendon</a>, London. The RAFG Communications Flight later in 1969 adopted the identity of <a href="No.%2060%20Squadron%20RAF">60 Squadron</a>, which had disbanded as a <a href="Gloster%20Javelin">Gloster Javelin</a> squadron at <a href="RAF%20Tengah">RAF Tengah</a> in Singapore the previous year.
In the 1970s, Wildenrath served as the initial home of the RAF '<a href="Harrier%20Jump%20Jet">Harrier Force</a>', which included numbers <a href="No.%203%20Squadron%20RAF">3</a>, <a href="No.%204%20Squadron%20RAF">4</a>, and <a href="No.%2020%20Squadron%20RAF">20</a> Squadrons, as well as 21(AS) Signal Regiment. In 1974–5, the Wildenrath station commander was <a href="Patrick%20Hine">Group Captain Patrick 'Paddy' Hine</a>, who later rose to <a href="Air%20Chief%20Marshal">Air Chief Marshal</a> and Joint Commander of all British forces during the <a href="Gulf%20War">Gulf War</a>.
1976-77 saw Wildenrath's role within RAF Germany change, as it became home to the command's <a href="air%20defence">air defence</a> squadrons, with <a href="No.%2019%20Squadron%20RAF">19 Squadron</a> and <a href="No.%2092%20Squadron%20RAF">92 Squadron</a> moving in from <a href="RAF%20Gutersloh">RAF Gutersloh</a>, having converted from the <a href="English%20Electric%20Lightning">English Electric Lightning</a> to the <a href="McDonnell%20Douglas%20F-4%20Phantom%20II%20in%20UK%20service">McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II</a>, and taking advantage of the Phantom's longer range. 3 and 4 Squadrons went the opposite direction, moving to Gutersloh, while 20 Squadron stood down from the Harrier, reforming at <a href="RAF%20Bruggen">RAF Bruggen</a> with the <a href="SEPECAT%20Jaguar">SEPECAT Jaguar GR1</a>.
While nominally a communication and light transport squadron, 60 Squadron also had a secondary, covert, role. Initially using the Hunting <a href="Percival%20Pembroke">Percival Pembroke</a>s, and later the <a href="Hawker%20Siddeley%20Andover">Hawker Siddeley Andover</a> from the mid-to-late 1980s, they were employed to take photographs of <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> and <a href="East%20Germany">East German</a> armed forces while flying along the <a href="West%20Berlin%20Air%20Corridor">Berlin air corridor</a>s. It also operated <a href="de%20Havilland%20Dove">DH Devon</a> and <a href="de%20Havilland%20Heron">DH Heron</a> aircraft. In addition to its other overt and covert functions, 60 Squadron also acted as visiting aircraft flight for Wildenrath, hosting almost every type of RAF and NATO aircraft and civilian 'trooper' <a href="BAC%20One-Eleven">BAC-111</a>s and <a href="Boeing%20737">Boeing 737</a>s.
Wildenrath was also home to an <a href="Army%20Air%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Army Air Corps</a> (AAC) flight operating light helicopters and fixed wing aircraft such as the <a href="Westland%20Scout">Westland Scout</a> and <a href="De%20Havilland%20Beaver">De Havilland Beaver</a>. The flight had its own hangar facilities on the base and various flight designations throughout its tenancy. Known initially as 12 Independent Liaison Flight, it then was renamed to 31 Flight, then 131 Flight Royal Corps of Transport (ex RASC), <a href="No.%20669%20Squadron%20AAC">No. 669 Squadron AAC</a>, and then in its last colours with a return to the 12 Flight title. The flight was manned by members of the corps under which the flight was named with the <a href="REME">REME</a> providing the technical servicing and maintenance of the aircraft.
On 1 May 1988, two airmen from the RAF Regiment squadron based at RAF Wildenrath were <a href="1988%20IRA%20attacks%20in%20the%20Netherlands">attacked by IRA armed assailants</a> whilst sitting in a car in the nearby Dutch town of <a href="Roermond">Roermond</a>. One of the airmen died from gunshot wounds, the other was seriously injured.
In October 1989, an RAF corporal and his infant daughter were shot dead at the petrol station in Wildenrath village, outside the RAF base. The <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Army">IRA</a> claimed that it was responsible for the murders.
Wildenrath had five <a href="Force%20dispersal">dispersal</a>s around its single runway. Alpha and Echo were not used in the normal flying operations of the station. No 19 Squadron operated from one of the three dispersals on the far (south) side of the airfield, designated 'Bravo Dispersal'. It also housed the two operational 'Battle Flights' for both fighter squadrons. No 92 Squadron flew from 'Delta Dispersal', with both squadrons using the <a href="hardened%20aircraft%20shelter">hardened aircraft shelter</a>s in 'Charlie Dispersal' for spare space to house Phantoms when necessary. Charlie Dispersal was also used by cross-trained 60 Squadron ground crew to turn around visiting aircraft during station exercises. The taxiway that ran parallel to the main runway and linked the three dispersals was used as the alternate runway for emergencies if the main runway was compromised. Alpha Dispersal was the site used for the Bloodhound launchers, and Echo Dispersal housed the fuel and lubricants storage section. 60 Squadron operated from the hangar close to the main Squadron Servicing hangar on the 'soft side' (northern) of the airbase.
Wildenrath closed as a flying base on 1 April 1992. The last flying squadron still present at that time, No 60 Squadron, moved to the nearby <a href="RAF%20Br%C3%BCggen">RAF Brüggen</a>.
RAF Wildenrath today.
Since 1997, the original <a href="airfield">airfield</a> and immediate environs comprise the <a href="Wegberg-Wildenrath%20Test%20and%20Validation%20Centre">Wegberg-Wildenrath Test and Validation Centre</a>, a facility for testing railway vehicles operated by <a href="Siemens">Siemens AG</a>. By 2007, the railway test tracks had taken over considerable areas of the airfield. All but the western threshold and overrun of the runway has been obliterated, and the eastern runway threshold is now a golf course, rather than the site of <a href="Bristol%20Bloodhound">Bloodhound</a> surface to air missiles. The north-east dispersal is completely taken over by <a href="Siding%20%28rail%29">siding</a>s, workshops, and <a href="Shunting%20%28rail%29">shunting loops</a>. Of the southern <a href="Force%20dispersal">dispersal</a>s, the central and eastern are bisected by the main railway oval test track. The south western dispersal and <a href="hardened%20aircraft%20shelter">hardened aircraft shelter</a>s have been dismantled and removed, with a small section of surviving <a href="taxiway">taxiway</a>s being used for recreational purposes by local residents.
The housing areas of the former RAF Wildenrath were originally used as overspill housing for <a href="RAF%20Bruggen">RAF Bruggen</a>, and then used to accommodate other UK military personnel until the end of September 2012, when the land was formally handed back to German local authorities. Since 2015, the former married quarters have been used as temporary accommodation for refugees, under the name 'Siedlung Petersholz' (Petersholz Estate) within the 'Zentrale Unterbringseinrichtung Wegberg' (Wegberg Central Accommodation Facility).
